Each fact should only include the smallest unit of information, but should be self-contained.\n"A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever and altered mental status. The patient has a history of Alzheimer dementia and is typically bed bound. His son found him confused with a warm and flushed complexion thus prompting his presentation. The patient has a past medical history of dementia, diabetes, and hypertension and typically has a visiting home nurse come to administer medications. Prior to examination, he is given haloperidol and diphenhydramine as he is combative and will not allow the nurses near him. His temperature is 102.9°F (39.4°C), blood pressure is 104/64 mmHg, pulse is 170/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical exam is notable for dry and flushed skin and a confused man. There is no skin breakdown, and flexion of the patient’s neck elicits no discomfort. Laboratory studies are drawn as seen below. |  | Hemoglobin: 15 g/dL | Hematocrit: 45% | Leukocyte count: 4,500/mm^3 with normal differential | Platelet count: 227,000/mm^3 |  | Serum: | Na+: 139 mEq/L | Cl-: 100 mEq/L | K+: 4.3 mEq/L | HCO3-: 24 mEq/L | BUN: 30 mg/dL | Glucose: 97 mg/dL | Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL | Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL | AST: 12 U/L | ALT: 10 U/L |  | Urine: | Color: Yellow | Bacteria: Absent | Nitrites: Negative | Red blood cells: Negative |  | An initial chest radiograph is unremarkable. The patient is given 3 liters of Ringer\'s lactate and an electric fan to cool off. Two hours later, his temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. The patient’s mental status is at the patient’s baseline according to the son."\nResponse with the list of atomic facts and nothing else, prepend each fact by an index starting from 1. No sub-list allowed.'}]

The initial chest radiograph is unremarkable.  \n\nNote: While the patient has a fever and flushed skin, which may suggest infection, there is no evidence of chills, cough, shortness of breath, urinary symptoms, or skin changes (such as rash or purpura) in the facts provided. Choose between the following ratings:\n"Very Confident" - The correct option is supported by all evidence, and there is enough evidence to eliminate the rest of the answers, so the option can be confirmed conclusively.\n"Somewhat Confident" - I have reasonably enough information to tell that the correct option is more likely than other options, more information is helpful to make a conclusive decision.\n"Neither Confident or Unconfident" - There are evident supporting the correct option, but further evidence is needed to be sure which one is the correct option.\n"Somewhat Unconfident" - There are evidence supporting more than one options, therefore more questions are needed to further distinguish the options.\n"Very Unconfident" - There are not enough evidence supporting any of the options, the likelihood of picking the correct option at this point is near random guessing.\n\nThink carefully step by step, respond with the chosen confidence rating ONLY and NOTHING ELSE.'}]

He reports a 5-month history of epigastric pain that improves with meals. He has lost 15 pounds since the pain started. His past medical history is significant for a prolactinoma for which he underwent transphenoidal resection. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 10 pack-year smoking history. His family history is notable for a maternal uncle with a parathyroid adenoma. His temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 18/min. After further workup, the patient is started on octreotide, an analogue of an endogenously produced hormone."\nResponse with the list of atomic facts and nothing else, prepend each fact by an index starting from 1. No sub-list allowed.'}]

The discomfort is located in the right upper quadrant. The physician suspects biliary colic. \n\nThese statements indicate that the patient has experienced intermittent discomfort in the right upper quadrant, which is consistent with biliary colic. However, there is no explicit mention of nausea, vomiting, or fever.\n\nTherefore, based on the provided facts, the patient has experienced episodes of right upper quadrant discomfort (which may be interpreted as pain), but there is no information about nausea, vomiting, or fever.\n\nAnswer: The patient has experienced intermittent discomfort in the right upper quadrant, but there is no information about nausea, vomiting, or fever. Thus, the patient cannot answer this question verbatim based on the given facts.\n\nFinal response: The patient cannot answer this question, please do not ask this question again.'}]}

The discomfort is located in the right upper quadrant. The physician suspects biliary colic. \n\nThese statements indicate that the patient has experienced intermittent discomfort in the right upper quadrant, which is consistent with biliary colic. However, there is no explicit mention of nausea, vomiting, or fever.\n\nTherefore, based on the provided facts, the patient has experienced episodes of right upper quadrant discomfort (which may be interpreted as pain), but there is no information about nausea, vomiting, or fever.\n\nAnswer: The patient has experienced intermittent discomfort in the right upper quadrant, but there is no information about nausea, vomiting, or fever. Choose between the following ratings:\n"Very Confident" - The correct option is supported by all evidence, and there is enough evidence to eliminate the rest of the answers, so the option can be confirmed conclusively.\n"Somewhat Confident" - I have reasonably enough information to tell that the correct option is more likely than other options, more information is helpful to make a conclusive decision.\n"Neither Confident or Unconfident" - There are evident supporting the correct option, but further evidence is needed to be sure which one is the correct option.\n"Somewhat Unconfident" - There are evidence supporting more than one options, therefore more questions are needed to further distinguish the options.\n"Very Unconfident" - There are not enough evidence supporting any of the options, the likelihood of picking the correct option at this point is near random guessing.\n\nThink carefully step by step, respond with the chosen confidence rating ONLY and NOTHING ELSE.'}]

These episodes self-resolve in a few seconds. Choose between the following ratings:\n"Very Confident" - The correct option is supported by all evidence, and there is enough evidence to eliminate the rest of the answers, so the option can be confirmed conclusively.\n"Somewhat Confident" - I have reasonably enough information to tell that the correct option is more likely than other options, more information is helpful to make a conclusive decision.\n"Neither Confident or Unconfident" - There are evident supporting the correct option, but further evidence is needed to be sure which one is the correct option.\n"Somewhat Unconfident" - There are evidence supporting more than one options, therefore more questions are needed to further distinguish the options.\n"Very Unconfident" - There are not enough evidence supporting any of the options, the likelihood of picking the correct option at this point is near random guessing.\n\nThink carefully step by step, respond with the chosen confidence rating ONLY and NOTHING ELSE.'}]

Choose between the following ratings:\n"Very Confident" - The correct option is supported by all evidence, and there is enough evidence to eliminate the rest of the answers, so the option can be confirmed conclusively.\n"Somewhat Confident" - I have reasonably enough information to tell that the correct option is more likely than other options, more information is helpful to make a conclusive decision.\n"Neither Confident or Unconfident" - There are evident supporting the correct option, but further evidence is needed to be sure which one is the correct option.\n"Somewhat Unconfident" - There are evidence supporting more than one options, therefore more questions are needed to further distinguish the options.\n"Very Unconfident" - There are not enough evidence supporting any of the options, the likelihood of picking the correct option at this point is near random guessing.\n\nThink carefully step by step, respond with the chosen confidence rating ONLY and NOTHING ELSE.'}, {'role': 'assistant', 'content': 'Very Unconfident'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'If there are missing features that prevent you from picking a confident and factual answer to the inquiry, consider which features are not yet asked about in the conversation log; then, consider which missing feature is the most important to ask the patient in order to provide the most helpful information toward a correct medical decision. You can ask about any relevant information about the patient’s case, such as family history, tests and exams results, treatments already done, etc. Consider what are the common questions asked in the specific subject relating to the patient’s known symptoms, and what the best and most intuitive doctor would ask. Ask ONE SPECIFIC ATOMIC QUESTION to address this feature. The question should be bite-sized, and NOT ask for too much at once. Make sure to NOT repeat any questions from the above conversation log. Each fact should only include the smallest unit of information, but should be self-contained.\n"A 31-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a persistent headache. She reports she has suffered from headaches since the age of 27 when she gained 12 kg (26.4 lb) after the birth of her second child. The headache is generalized and throbbing in nature. It worsens in the morning and is aggravated with coughing, laughing, and sneezing. The patient’s blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and the temperature is 36.6℃ (97.9℉). The patient’s weight is 101 kg (222.7 lb), height is 165 cm (5.4 ft), and BMI is 36.7 kg/m2. Examination reveals papilledema. Head CT scan does not reveal any abnormalities. Lumbar puncture shows an opening pressure of 32 cm H2O. The patient is prescribed a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, acetazolamide, for idiopathic intracranial hypertension."\nResponse with the list of atomic facts and nothing else, prepend each fact by an index starting from 1. No sub-list allowed.'}]

The patient was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 8 months ago and is currently undergoing treatment. His vital signs are within normal limits. She reports that her symptoms started 1 week ago and have gotten progressively worse. The chest pain is left-sided and is exacerbated by coughing or deep breaths. She also endorses a 6-month history of joint pains involving her knees, elbows, and digits. She does not have a significant medical or surgical history. She takes ibuprofen as needed. She works as a pre-school teacher. The patient’s temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, and respirations are 17/min with an oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. On physical examination, a friction rub upon inspiration/expiration and crackles are appreciated at the base of the left lung. She has an erythematous rash that spans the bilateral cheeks and nose. There are also scattered ecchymoses on her arms and legs. A chest radiograph shows a small left-sided pleural effusion. A complete blood count is obtained, as shown below: |  | Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL | Hematocrit: 28% | Leukocyte count: 1,500/mm^3 with normal differential | Platelet count: 80,000/mm^3 |  | A urinalysis shows elevated protein levels. Serologic antibodies are pending."\nResponse with the list of atomic facts and nothing else, prepend each fact by an index starting from 1. No sub-list allowed.'}]

The symptoms have progressively worsened.\n10. The patient has a 6-month history of joint pains.\n11. The joint pains involve the knees.\n12. The joint pains involve the elbows.\n13. The joint pains involve the digits.\n14. The patient does not have a significant medical history.\n15. The patient does not have a significant surgical history.\n16. The patient takes ibuprofen as needed.\n17. The patient works as a pre-school teacher.\n18. The patient\'s temperature is 99°F.\n19. The patient\'s temperature is 37.2°C.\n20. The patient\'s blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg.\n21. The patient\'s pulse is 89/min.\n22. The patient\'s respirations are 17/min.\n23. The patient\'s oxygen saturation is 93% on room air.\n24. On physical examination, a friction rub is present upon inspiration and expiration.\n25. On physical examination, crackles are appreciated at the base of the left lung.\n26. The patient has an erythematous rash on the bilateral cheeks.\n27. The patient has an erythematous rash on the nose.\n28. The patient has scattered ecchymoses on the arms.\n29. The patient has scattered ecchymoses on the legs.\n30. A chest radiograph shows a small left-sided pleural effusion.\n31. A complete blood count is obtained.\n32. The hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL.\n33. The hematocrit level is 28%.\n34. The leukocyte count is 1,500/mm³.\n35. The leukocyte differential is normal.\n36. The platelet count is 80,000/mm³.\n37. The urinalysis shows elevated protein levels.\n38. Serologic antibodies are pending.\n\nQuestion from the doctor: "Has the patient experienced any recent episodes of coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion?"\n\nStatements that answer the question:'}]
[learning process] need understand the content of patient state {'initial_info': 'A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and chest pain.', 'interaction_history': [{'question': 'Does the patient have a history of smoking, recent weight loss, or family history of heart disease or lung cancer?', 'answer': 'The patient cannot answer this question, please do not ask this question again.'}, {'question': 'Has the patient experienced any recent episodes of coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion?', 'answer': "The patient has chest pain that is exacerbated by coughing and deep breaths. The symptoms of dyspnea and chest pain started 1 week ago and have progressively worsened. The patient does not report hemoptysis. The question specifically asks about coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion. While the patient has dyspnea and coughing-related chest pain, there is no mention of shortness of breath worsening with exertion.\n\nTherefore, the only relevant statement is:\n\n- The patient has chest pain that is exacerbated by coughing.\n\nHowever, the question specifically asks about coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion. The patient's dyspnea is described as progressive and worsening, but not specifically with exertion. There is no mention of exertion-related worsening of shortness of breath.\n\nThus, none of the facts directly confirm recent episodes of coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion.\n\nFinal answer: The patient cannot answer this question, please do not ask this question again."}]}

While the patient has dyspnea and coughing-related chest pain, there is no mention of shortness of breath worsening with exertion.\n\nTherefore, the only relevant statement is:\n\n- The patient has chest pain that is exacerbated by coughing.\n\nHowever, the question specifically asks about coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion. The patient\'s dyspnea is described as progressive and worsening, but not specifically with exertion. There is no mention of exertion-related worsening of shortness of breath.\n\nThus, none of the facts directly confirm recent episodes of coughing, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath that worsens with exertion.\n\nFinal answer: The patient cannot answer this question, please do not ask this question again.\nDoctor Question: Has the patient experienced any recent fever, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss?\nPatient Response: The patient cannot answer this question, please do not ask this question again.\nQUESTION: Which of the following is the primary cause of the patient’s lab results?\nOPTIONS: A: Hematologic malignancy, B: Immune-mediated destruction, C: Mechanical shearing, D: Viral infection\nYOUR TASK: Medical conditions are complex, so you should seek to understand their situations across many features. Choose between the following ratings:\n"Very Confident" - The correct option is supported by all evidence, and there is enough evidence to eliminate the rest of the answers, so the option can be confirmed conclusively.\n"Somewhat Confident" - I have reasonably enough information to tell that the correct option is more likely than other options, more information is helpful to make a conclusive decision.\n"Neither Confident or Unconfident" - There are evident supporting the correct option, but further evidence is needed to be sure which one is the correct option.\n"Somewhat Unconfident" - There are evidence supporting more than one options, therefore more questions are needed to further distinguish the options.\n"Very Unconfident" - There are not enough evidence supporting any of the options, the likelihood of picking the correct option at this point is near random guessing.\n\nThink carefully step by step, respond with the chosen confidence rating ONLY and NOTHING ELSE.'}, {'role': 'assistant', 'content': 'Neither Confident or Unconfident'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'If there are missing features that prevent you from picking a confident and factual answer to the inquiry, consider which features are not yet asked about in the conversation log; then, consider which missing feature is the most important to ask the patient in order to provide the most helpful information toward a correct medical decision.
